text:
Do noisy eaters throw you into a rage? This could be the scientific reason why... It's not just down to you being grumpy (maybe) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
If the sound of someone eating a bag of crisps can throw you into a near-murderous rage, or if someone chewing gum or breathing heavily can bring you out in a cold sweat - we've got some good news for you. 
It's not just down to you being grumpy (although you may also be grumpy). Read More Microwaving fish, slurping tea and loud typing: Things you only know if you work in an office 
Scientists have found that people who get angry because of someone chewing or breathing loudly may actually have a genuine brain abnormality. 
In research published by a northern university scientists have found a physical basis for the people suffering from a condition known as misophonia. 
Misophonia is a condition where people have a hatred of sounds such as eating, chewing or repeated pen clicking. 
These 'trigger sounds' can promote an immediate and intense fight or flight feeling. 
In research published in 'Current Biology', scientists claim to have identified evidence of clear changes in the structure of the brain’s frontal lobe in sufferers of misophonia and also report changes in the brain activity. Read More 
By using brain imaging researchers found brain activity that came from a different connectivity pattern to the frontal lobe. 
This suggests that the condition is real despite previous medical scepticism. (Photo: Getty Images) 
When the participant hears 'trigger sounds' researchers found changes in the brain activity along with increased heart rate and sweating. 
The different patterns in the "emotional control mechanism" causes brain activity to go into overdrive on hearing trigger sounds. 
Dr Sukhbinder Kumar from the Institute of Neuroscience at Newcastle University and the Wellcome Centre for NeuroImaging at University College London (UCL) led the research which was supported by Wellcome. He said: “For many people with misophonia, this will come as welcome news as for the first time we have demonstrated a difference in brain structure and function in sufferers. Read More Man filmed yelling vile racist abuse at bus passenger 
“Patients with misophonia had strikingly similar clinical features and yet the syndrome is not recognised in any of the current clinical diagnostic schemes. This study demonstrates the critical brain changes as further evidence to convince a sceptical medical community that this is a genuine disorder.” 
In one case study provided by the university a misophonia sufferer said her GP laughed when she told him about her symptoms. 
Olana Tansley-Hancock, 29, from Ashford in Kent, was eight years old when family meals became unbearable for her. 
She said: "The noise of my family eating forced me to retreat to my own bedroom for meals. 
"I can only describe it as a feeling of wanting to punch people in the face when I heard the noise of them eating - and anyone who knows me will say that doesn't sound like me." 
Tim Griffiths, Professor of Cognitive Neurology at Newcastle University and UCL adds: “I hope this will reassure sufferers. I was part of the sceptical community myself until we saw patients in the clinic and understood how strikingly similar the features are. 
“We now have evidence to establish the basis for the disorder through the differences in brain control mechanism in misophonia. This will suggest therapeutic manipulations and encourage a search for similar mechanisms in other conditions associated with abnormal emotional reactions.” Like us on Facebook
